Massachusetts General Laws c. 212, \u00a.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws c. 212, § 4.

Massachusetts General Laws c. 223, \u00a.proposition: Venue is proper in Norfolk County pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws c. 223, § 1, as the incident giving rise to this action occurred in Norfolk County, and the defendant operates its business in Norfolk County.

*Scott v. Garfield*, 454 Mass. 790, 793.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, businesses that invite patrons onto their premises owe those patrons a duty to exercise reasonable care in maintaining the premises in a reasonably safe condition.
*Scott v. Garfield*, 454 Mass. 790, 793.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns landlords’ duties under the implied warranty of habitability to tenants and their lawful visitors in a residential setting, not the duty of care owed by businesses to patrons. The only general premises-liability principle it recites (via Mounsey) is that landowners owe a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors, without distinguishing businesses or invitees specifically. Thus, it does not specifically establish the business‑invitee duty described in the proposition.
*Scott v. Garfield*, 454 Mass. 790, 793.relevant_excerpt: “Moreover, we have long since eliminated much of the legal significance attached to the question of status in our tort law. See Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973) (doing away with distinctions between categories of licensee and invitee and holding that landowner owes duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors).”

*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.raw_text: *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.*, 448 Mass. 780, 783 (2007)
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, businesses that invite patrons onto their premises owe those patrons a duty to exercise reasonable care in maintaining the premises in a reasonably safe condition.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the general Massachusetts rule that a store owner must maintain its property in a reasonably safe condition, reflecting a duty of reasonable care owed to invitees. Although the main thrust of the case is adopting the mode-of-operation approach to notice, the court reaffirms this underlying duty as part of the traditional premises liability framework, so it directly supports the proposition about the business’s duty to patrons on its premises.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.relevant_excerpt: “Historically, Massachusetts has also followed the traditional approach governing premises liability. A store owner has been required to maintain its property ‘in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1973).”

*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.raw_text: *Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.*, 363 Mass. 165, 166 (1973)
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.proposition: The defendant owed the plaintiff, as an invitee, a duty to ensure that the restaurant, including the hallway leading to the restroom, was maintained in a reasonably safe condition and that patrons were protected from dangerous conditions.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states the duty of a party controlling business premises toward its patrons: to use due care to keep the premises provided for their use in a reasonably safe condition or to warn them of dangers not likely to be known to them. Although the facts concern a subway stairway rather than a restaurant hallway, the court articulates the general invitee-duty principle that would apply to areas such as a restaurant and its hallway leading to a restroom.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.relevant_excerpt: “The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know.”

*Young v. Atlantic Ave. Rink Corp.*, 323.raw_text: *Young v. Atlantic Ave. Rink Corp.*, 323 Mass. 401, 402 (1948)
*Young v. Atlantic Ave. Rink Corp.*, 323.proposition: The defendant owed the plaintiff, as an invitee, a duty to ensure that the restaurant, including the hallway leading to the restroom, was maintained in a reasonably safe condition and that patrons were protected from dangerous conditions.
*Young v. Atlantic Ave. Rink Corp.*, 323.support_reasoning: This case is a Massachusetts workers’ compensation decision about whether an unwitnessed workplace fall ‘arose out of’ employment and the effect of a statutory evidentiary presumption. It does not involve premises liability, invitees, restaurants, or hallways to restrooms, nor does it discuss a landowner’s duty to maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition. Accordingly, it provides no authority for the stated proposition about a restaurant owner’s duty to patrons as invitees.
*Young v. Atlantic Ave. Rink Corp.*, 323.relevant_excerpt: “The question to be decided is whether the employee’s injury arose out of his employment. It is apparently conceded that the injury occurred in the course of his employment. There is nothing to show what caused the employee to fall on the level of the fifth floor landing where he was found… It may reasonably be inferred from the evidence that the employee may have sustained a coronary attack which caused him to fall to the floor.”

*Goddard v. Boston & Maine R.R.*, 179 Ma.raw_text: *Goddard v. Boston & Maine R.R.*, 179 Mass. 52, 54 (1901) (a defendant is liable for injuries caused by a condition it either knew of or should have discovered with reasonable diligence).
*Goddard v. Boston & Maine R.R.*, 179 Ma.proposition: The defendant knew or should have known about the dangerous condition in the hallway, as evidenced by the statements of staff acknowledging awareness of the hazard and the fact that it remained unaddressed for an extended period.
*Goddard v. Boston & Maine R.R.*, 179 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion fragment only addresses the possibility that the banana peel causing the injury may have been dropped moments before the accident, implying the railroad may not have had time to discover or remedy it. It does not articulate or apply a rule about liability for conditions the defendant knew or should have known about, nor does it discuss staff awareness or an extended period of hazard. Thus, it does not support the specific constructive-knowledge proposition for which it is cited.
*Goddard v. Boston & Maine R.R.*, 179 Ma.relevant_excerpt: "The banana skin upon which the plaintiff stepped and which caused him to slip may have been dropped within a minute by one of the persons who was leaving the train. It is unnecessary to go further to decide the case."

*Santos v. Chrysler Corp.*, 430 Mass. 19.proposition: The defendant’s failure to promptly address the hazard or provide any warning created a foreseeable risk of harm to the plaintiff and other patrons.
*Santos v. Chrysler Corp.*, 430 Mass. 19.support_reasoning: The opinion is a products-liability/design-defect case about a defective braking system in a minivan; it does not involve a premises owner’s or defendant’s failure to promptly remedy a hazard or provide warnings to patrons. The court discusses notice to Chrysler and evidence of defect, but nowhere frames liability in terms of a duty to address a known hazardous condition or to warn plaintiffs or other patrons. Thus, it does not support the specific proposition about failure to address or warn of a hazard creating foreseeable risk to patrons.
*Santos v. Chrysler Corp.*, 430 Mass. 19.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff alleged that premature rear wheel lockup was a design defect… The plaintiff did not rely on the other incident evidence to prove the existence of a defect in Chrysler minivans. Evidence of a defect was introduced in the form of expert testimony. The other incident testimony was put in evidence to establish notice, to corroborate the alleged defect, and to refute evidence that the minivan was designed without safety hazards.”

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.proposition: The defendant’s failure to promptly address the hazard or provide any warning created a foreseeable risk of harm to the plaintiff and other patrons.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction and holds that property owners owe lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care as to snow and ice, including making reasonable efforts to protect them from dangers the owner knows or should know about. It expressly grounds liability in foreseeable harm and the burden of avoiding the risk, which encompasses an owner’s failure to address or warn of a hazardous snow/ice condition. While the case does not describe this defendant’s conduct as such in a factual holding, its legal rule supports the general proposition about foreseeable risk from failing to remedy or warn of hazards.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to “act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.” … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.

*Donovan v. Vigeant*, 77 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: As a direct and proximate result of the defendant’s negligence, the plaintiff sustained physical injuries, endured pain and suffering, and incurred special damages including medical expenses and lost wages.
*Donovan v. Vigeant*, 77 Mass. App. Ct..case_name: Keystone Freight Corp. v. Bartlett Consolidated, Inc.
*Donovan v. Vigeant*, 77 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns counterclaim rules and the anti-SLAPP statute in a billing/abuse of process context; it does not involve a negligence action for personal injuries, nor does it discuss proximate cause, physical injury, pain and suffering, or special damages such as medical expenses and lost wages. The factual background involves property damage to a guardrail and a collection action over repair costs, not bodily injury to a plaintiff. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the quoted negligence-damages proposition.
*Donovan v. Vigeant*, 77 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: On April 4, 2005, Jeremy Petrosso was a truck driver for Keystone, a freight company. On that afternoon, Petrosso collided with a guardrail on the westbound side of Route 2 in Fitchburg, while attempting to avoid hitting an animal in the road. The force of the collision caused the truck to straddle and run over a portion of the guardrail. ... After determining that there were no injuries, McDonald guided Petrosso off the guardrail and directed him toward a side street to wait for the investigating officer.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B;.proposition: Prejudgment interest, pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
